bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, December 18, 1939

div1.p: Hutchison thanks Hench for advice on Washington and Jefferson College Founders' Day preparations. He mentions additional plans relative to this. Hutchison thanks Hench for his contribution.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, December 18, 1939

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
December 18, 1939

div1.p:
You have certainly done a swell job in
analyzing the whole situation in regard to the medical
possibilities for Founders' Day. I am delighted to
have this authoritative study on your part and I
cannot tell you how much I appreciate it. I am
very definitely convinced that your suggestion of
Doctor Sawyer is the right one for the main speaker
on the morning of Founders' Day. I am going to
propose this to the trustees at the next meeting and
see if we can sign him up. I find in my experience
that it is better to finish one part of it at a time,
and if we can get him then we can go on to the
question of the evening dinner which is a different
problem.

If we have Doctor W A Sawyer Director Int Health AraDiv Rockefeller Fo in the speech of the
morning dealing with this yellow fever incident, and
if we have the play the night before and the background
talk by yourself, it is entirely probable that we will
need to move to some other phase of medicine for the
dinner. This outline which we have now will constitute
enough treatment of the Lazear problem and the plan
will be to have something quite different for that dinner
Founders' Day evening, though it should be along medical
lines. It may be that something may be worked out in
the reapproachment of Washington and Jefferson College
and Jefferson Medical School. As you know, there is a
very involved relationship due to these portraits which
were stolen and ultimately given to Jefferson Medical
School. It may be that the new Dean of that School is
a good speaker, that we can persuade them to return
these famous portraits to this College on that occasion
and that we can thus make that dinner one dealing
primarily with medical education. This is just an idea
that is playing through my mind and I pass it on to you.

div1.p:
If you happen by chance to have any reactions
concerning the speaking ability of the new Dean of the
Jefferson Medical let me have them. Of course I can
pick this up in Philadelphia, so do not go out of your
way in the matter.

Since I wrote you, the students have put
on “Yellow Jack” and it was very successfully and
effectively done. This means that we are sure of being
able to put it on next year with success. We are
profoundly disappointed that Sidney Howard himself
was killed this summer.

Thank you for increasing your pledge to one
hundred and fifty and please bear in mind that you can
take three years to pay this, doing it when and as it
is convenient. The requirement that it carry “Lafayette
'16” may have been intended as a joke, but I have
suggested to the men here that it would be a very
effective thing to put on there in view of the large
number of names carrying W. and J. numerals. I am
hoping they will do it and think they will.

I still do not know when I can get out there,
but I hope it will be quite soon. It depends a little
bit on how Harriet's health is and how campaign
measures go forward in other respects.

I hope that you folks have a lovely
Christmas and that there will be much happiness in your
home. With kindest regards,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Hutch Doctor Philips S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
